item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Wowchemy’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further event details, including page elements such as image galleries, can be added to the body of this page.

item.title: You want an online portfolio
item.description:
As a data scientist, you want an online portfolio.

Given that a data scientist’s work often involves creating a narrative that explains and motivates a choice, what better means is there to demonstrate your ability to weave a story, if not through an online portfolio?

Still, you should ask, “demonstrate to whom?” Consider your audience: are you addressing a prospective customer, a future employer, or the data science community-at-large? In my case, my audience comprises everyone who has decided (or may decide) to study data science.

To those who are only just getting started in data science, may I suggest that your primary audience is your future employer?

Still not convinced? What if, instead, you were a photographer? Would you describe your work using only words? Of course not. You would showcase your photographs somehow (or at least, you would share your photos). The same is true for many professionals with visual products, including architects, interior designers, artists, and remodelers. A portfolio of one’s work is always beneficial.

As for my experience, I have an extensive portfolio of work in software engineering on databases, architecture designs, fancy code segments, and testing, all of which are barren as to their visual appeal. Finally, as a future data scientist, I have the chance to show something that is at least visually appealing, if not cool.

Where should you start? The next logical question is where you should begin to build your online portfolio. I recommend starting with two sources:

  • 9 of the Best Data Analytics Portfolios on the Web by Will Hillier

  • How to Build a Data Science Portfolio by Michael Galarnyk

Hillier’s advice is subtle. In his article on the best online portfolios (Hillier 2020), Hillier explains that reviewing outstanding online portfolios is a great way to understand what to say and how to say it.

“Storytelling is a key skill for data analytics, a field where facts and figures [come together] to weave a narrative (Hillier 2020).”

Hillier explains that your online portfolio is an introduction to others, if not your first introduction. First impressions count. So then, what impression do you want to make? Hillier speaks to many first impressions that are possible: professional, expressive, clear, convincing, communicator, approachable, transparent, focus, direct, and personal.

Hillier emphasizes that your online portfolio is an opportunity to present your work front-and-center.

“Keep your portfolio focused. Use practical examples that highlight important skills like data wrangling, analytics, and visualization (Hillier 2020).”

Galarnyk’s advice is direct. In his article on building an online portfolio (Galarnyk 2018), Galarnyk works his way through an exhaustive set of considerations.

Galarnyk describes how an online portfolio can be the means to circumvent an experience requirement: your project work itself may be motivation enough to speak with a hiring manager. So while you may not have the requisite number of years of experience, you may have work results that align with a hiring manager’s needs. Ten years of work experience doing the wrong thing doesn’t mean you have ten years of work experience – just saying.

Interestingly, Galarnyk describes what types of projects to include or not include in a portfolio. For example, a rudimentary project that works with data sets available to all data science students is an example of what not to include in a portfolio. Instead, Galarnyk emphasizes what makes a project notable could be the data itself. Galarnyk suggests that “[web scraping] is a great way to get interesting data,” for example.

How should you start? There is no doubt that there are many paths to creating a website. Creating an online portfolio is no different.

Start from scratch. One path forward is to create your online presence from scratch using technologies for building websites. Nikulski (Nikulski 2020) describes this approach by starting your site from (nearly) raw HTML and javascript code. You can certainly go this route if your goal is to learn the underlying technologies described. But I would not go this route, nor would I ever recommend it to others, precisely because my goal is to present my work, not learn web technologies. A deep-dive into such web technologies is career-move onto itself.

Use powerful web frameworks. Another path forward is to use a well-established web framework such as WordPress to build your site. Suffice to say that I call WordPress a framework (others do not (McFarlin 2016)) because it ties together the sufficient technologies to build a robust web presence. To be clear, according to De Valk (De Valk 2019), WordPress is the basis for over one-third of the top 10 million sites on the web. Having worked with WordPress for more than ten years, I have no doubt I could build my web presence using WordPress. However, I am choosing not to use WordPress for my online portfolio.

When in Rome, do as the Romans do (Wikipedia 2021). To my surprise, you can build your online presence using a technical approach that caters to data science presentations. Yihui Xie (Xie 2020), now with RStudio (RStudio 2021), created an open-source R package called Bookdown that sits on top of a static site generator called Hugo. Normally, I would shy away from relying on any new technology. However, I am making an exception here because, as noted on Xie’s archive page, a substantial number of data science authors use Bookdown to render their online books.

Not that Bookdown isn’t new enough, Blogdown is newer still. And I am going with Blogdown to build my online portfolio. Once I started down that slippery slope using Bookdown, I necessarily slipped into Blogdown along the way.

I will end this post with my bottom-line. I am using Blogdown because it supports the following capabilities:

  • Supports MathJax/Katex for math expressions,
  • Supports PNGs as figures,
  • Supports references/bibliographies using BibTeX,
  • Supports LaTeX graphics,
  • Supports R demonstrations, including fancy plots,
  • Supports user interaction using Javascript,
  • Supports Python demonstrations,
  • Supports Sass, a preprocessor scripting language,
  • Supports a rich set of website templates,
  • Employs a static web site framework,
  • Includes a large assortment of authoring constructs,
  • Deploys as a static site directly from Github, and
  • Employs version-control using Github.

For more details regarding Blogdown and the Hugo framework, please see my upcoming post TBD.

item.title: Tikz - Using Latex Graphics within R Markdown
item.description:
Tikz is an interesting approach to adding Latex Graphics to your R Markdown. I could not get this to work original because I had installed TeXLive 2020 on my machine. I chose to load TeXLive because I thought it would be more comprehensive than using Yuihi’s recommendation TinyTeX. Once I uninstalled TeXLive (completely, as in rm -rf /usr/local/texlive), and then installed both pdftools and TinyTeX, then (and only then) did I get the Tikz engine to work.

install.packages("pdftools")
tinytex::install_tinytex()

Try Latex

  • (Yihui) https://github.com/yihui/knitr-examples/blob/master/058-engine-tikz.Rmd
  • https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tikzDevice/vignettes/tikzDevice.pdf

item.title: Axioms of Probability Theory
item.description:
Axioms of Probability

Definition 1 (PROBABILITY SPACE) A PROBABILITY SPACE has three components:

  1. a sample space \(\Omega\), which is the set of all possible OUTCOMES of the random process modeled by the probability space;

  2. a family of sets \(\mathcal{F}\) representing the allowable EVENTS, where each set in \(\mathcal{F}\) is a subset of the sample \(\Omega\); and;

  3. a probability function \(Pr: \mathcal{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) that satisfies Definition 2

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 2)

Definition 2 (Probability Function) A probability function is any function \(Pr:\mathcal{F}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) that satisfies the following conditions:

  1. for any event \(E\), \(0 \le Pr(E) \le 1\);

  2. \(Pr(\Omega) = 1\);

  3. for any finite or countably infinite sequence of pairwise mutually disjoint events \(E_1, E_2, E_3, ...,\)

\[\begin{equation} Pr \left( \bigcup_{i \ge 1}E_i \right) = \sum_{i \ge 1} Pr(E_i). \end{equation}\]

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 2)

1 Set Theory

1.1 Definitions

Definition 1.1 (SET) A SET is a well-defined collection of objects.

We use upper-case letters to denote sets: \(A, B, X, Y\).

Definition 1.2 (ELEMENTS or MEMBERS) The objects in a set are called ELEMENTS or MEMBERS of the set.

We use lower-case letters to denote elements of a set: \(a, b, x, y\).

Given a set \(A\) and an element \(x\), we write

\[\begin{equation} x \in A \end{equation}\]

if \(x\) is an element of \(A\) and

\[\begin{equation} x \not\in A \end{equation}\]

if it is not.

Definition 1.3 (SUBSET) Given two sets \(A\) and \(B\), if every element of set \(A\) is also an element of set \(B\), then we say \(A\) is a SUBSET of \(B\), and we write

\[A \subseteq B \ \ \equiv \ \ \{x : x \in A \rightarrow x \in B\}\]

However, if there is at least one element of set \(A\) that is not an element of set \(B\), then we say \(A\) is NOT A SUBSET of \(B\), and we write

\[A \nsubseteq B \ \ \equiv \ \ \exists x \{x : x \in A \rightarrow x \notin B\}. \text{ HELP HELP HELP HELP }\]
Definition 1.4 (SET EQUALITY) Two sets \(A\) and \(B\) are equal, denoted \(A = B\), if and only if \(A \subseteq B\) and \(B \subseteq A.\)
Definition 1.5 (UNIVERSAL SET) All sets under investigation are assumed to be contained
in some larger fixed set called the UNIVERSAL SET, denoted \(\Omega\). HELP HELP HELP HELP

Definition 1.6 (SET COMPLEMENT) Given a set \(A\), \(A \subseteq \Omega\), the complement of set \(A,\) denoted \(A^c\), is the set containing all elements in \(\Omega\) but not in \(A\).

\[\begin{equation} A^c = \{x : x \in \Omega \text{ and } x \notin A \} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} A^c = \Omega - A \end{equation}\]

Definition 1.7 (SET UNION) The UNION of sets \(A\) and \(B,\) denoted \(A \cup B,\) is the set containing all elements in either \(A\) or \(B\) or both.

\[\begin{equation} A \cup B = \{ x : x \in A \text{ or } x \in B \} \end{equation}\]

Definition 1.8 (SET INTERSECTION) The INTERSECTION of sets \(A\) and \(B,\) denoted \(A \cap B,\) is the set containing all elements in both \(A\) and \(B\).

\[\begin{equation} A \cap B = \{ x : x \in A \text{ and } x \in B \} \end{equation}\]
Definition 1.9 (SET DIFFERENCE) The DIFFERENCE of sets \(A\) and \(B,\) denoted \(A \backslash B\) or \(A-B\), is the set of all elements in \(A\) but not in \(B.\)

\[\begin{equation} A \backslash B = \{ x : x \in A \text{ and } x \notin B \} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} A \backslash B = A \cap \overline{B} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} A - B = \{ x : x \in A \text{ and } x \notin B \} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} A - B = A \cap \overline{B} \end{equation}\]

Definition 1.10 (SET SYMMETRIC DIFFERENCE) The SYMMETRIC DIFFERENCE of sets \(A\) and \(B,\) denoted \(A \Delta B,\) is the set of all elements that are in \(A\) or \(B\) but not in both.

\[\begin{equation} A \Delta B = \{ x : x \in A \cup B \text{ and } x \notin A \cap B\} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} A \Delta B = (A \cap \overline{B}) \cup (\overline{A} \cap B) \end{equation}\] SHOW PROOF - SHOW PROOF - SHOW PROOF

\[\begin{equation} A \Delta B = (A \backslash B) \cup (B \backslash A) \end{equation}\] SHOW PROOF - SHOW PROOF - SHOW PROOF

Definition 1.11 (MUTALLY EXCLUSVE) Two sets \(A\) and \(B\) are called MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE if they contain no common element,

\[\begin{equation} A \cap B = \emptyset. \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} A \text{ and } B \text{ are mutually exclusive } \equiv A \cap B = \emptyset \end{equation}\]

The terms DISJOINT and MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE are equivalent.

Definition 1.12 (EMPTY SET) The set containing no elements is called the EMPTY SET, denoted as \(\emptyset.\)

\[\begin{equation} \emptyset = \Omega^c \end{equation}\]

The terms EMPTY SET and NULL are equivalent.

\(\newcommand{\qedsymbolred} {\color{red} {\rule{0.5em}{0.5em}}}\) \(\newcommand{\qedsymbolblack}{\color{black}{\rule{0.5em}{0.5em}}}\) \(\newcommand{\qedsymbol} {\color{white}{\rule{0.5em}{0.5em}}}\)

Show

\[\begin{equation} Pr(A \cup B) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) - Pr(A \cap B) \tag{1} \end{equation}\]

where the sets \(A\) and \(B\) are subsets of the sample space \(\Omega\), \(A \cup B\) denotes the union of two sets \(A\) and \(B\), \(A \cap B\) denotes the intersection of two sets \(A\) and \(B\), and \(Pr(E)\) is a probability function that assigns a probability \(p\) to an event \(E \subseteq \Omega\) with probability \(0 \le p \le 1\).

For this proof, consider the relationship between the sets \(A \cup B\), \(A\), and \(B\). For example, Figure 1 uses a Venn diagram to illustrate one relationship between these sets.

Figure 1: Typical venn diagram for \(A \cup B\)

The problem with the Venn diagram shown by Figure 1 is that the sets shown are not mutually disjoint. When writing proofs involving probability, you need to work with sets that are mutually disjoint. When the sets are mutually disjoint, then and only then can you use the third condition of a probability function, as given by Eq. (2),

For any finite or countably infinite sequence of pairwise mutually disjoint events \(E_1, E_2, E_3, ...,\)

\[\begin{equation} Pr \left( \bigcup_{i \ge 1}E_i \right) = \sum_{i \ge 1} Pr(E_i). \tag{2} \end{equation}\]

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 3)

Figure 2 illustrates a different Venn diagram that uses two mutually disjoint sets to represent the union \(A \cup B\).

Figure 2: The union of \(A \cup B\) using mutually disjoint sets

If we use the two sets as illustrated by Figure 2 then we can apply Eq. (2).

Our strategy is as follows. Given the equality

\[\begin{equation} A \cup B = A \cup ( \overline{A} \cup B) \tag{3} \end{equation}\]

with the two mutually disjoint sets \(A\) and \((\overline{A} \cup B)\), then we can use Eq. (2) to say

\[\begin{equation} Pr(A \cup B) = Pr(A) + Pr(\overline{A} \cap B). \end{equation}\]

Provided we can show

\[\begin{equation} Pr(\overline{A} \cap B) = Pr(B) - Pr(A \cap B), \end{equation}\]

then we can combine our last two expressions to complete our proof.

Prove Eq. (3), repeated below,

\[\begin{equation} A \cup B = A \cup ( B \cap \overline{A} ). \tag{3} \end{equation}\]

We will use the following properties from set theory for our proof,

\[\begin{align} A = & \ A \cap \Omega \ \ \ \textrm{ for any set } A \subseteq \Omega, \tag{Property 1}\\ \Omega = & \ A \cup \overline{A} \ \ \ \textrm{ for any set } A \subseteq \Omega. \tag{Property 2} \end{align}\]

The proof of Eq. (3) follows:

\[\begin{align} A \cup B = & \ (A \cup B) && \textrm{... Identity} \\ = & \ (A \cup B) \cap \Omega && \textrm{... by Property 1} \\ = & \ (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup \overline{A}) && \textrm{... by Property 2} \\ = & \ A \cup (B \cap \overline{A}) && \textrm{... } \cup \textrm{ distributes over } \cap \\ &&\qedsymbolblack \end{align}\]

Show

\[\begin{equation} B = (B \cap A) \cup (B \cap \overline{A}). \tag{4} \end{equation}\]

The proof follows:

\[\begin{align} B = & \ (B) && \textrm{... Identity} \\ = & \ (B) \cap \Omega && \textrm{... by Property 1} \\ = & \ (B) \cap (A \cup \overline{A}) && \textrm{... by Property 2} \\ = & \ (B \cap A) \cup (B \cap \overline{A}) && \textrm{... } \cap \textrm{ distributes over } \cup \\ &&\qedsymbolblack \end{align}\]

Given Eqs. (3) and (4), we can now apply Eq. (2) from the probability function,

\[\begin{equation} Pr(A \cup B) = Pr(A) + Pr(B \cap \overline{A}), \tag{5} \end{equation}\]

and

\[\begin{equation} Pr(B) = Pr(B \cap A) + Pr(B \cap \overline{A}), \tag{6} \end{equation}\]

If we solve for \(Pr(B \cap \overline{A})\) using Eq. (6),

\[\begin{equation} Pr(B \cap \overline{A}) = Pr(B) - Pr(b \cap A), \tag{7} \end{equation}\]

and then substitute this value of \(Pr(B \cap \overline{A})\) from Eq. (7) into Eq. (5), then we obtain our desired result,

\[\begin{align} Pr(A \cup B) = & \ Pr(A) + Pr(B \cap \overline{A}) \\[1em] = & \ Pr(A) + Pr(B) - Pr(B \cap A). \\ \end{align}\]

\[\begin{equation} Pr(A \cup B) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) - Pr(B \cap A) \end{equation}\]

References

Mitzenmacher, Michael, and Eli Upfal. 2017. Probability and Computing: Randomization and Probabilistic Techniques in Algorithms and Data Analysis. Kindle. Cambridge, United Kingdom: Cambridge University Press.

1 Events and Probability

1.1 Application: Verifying Polynomial Identities

Let \(F(x)\) and \(G(x)\) be polynomials, where \(F(x)\) is the product [of monomials] \(F(x) = \prod^d_{i=1} (x - a_i)\) and \(G(x)\) is in its canonical form. Transforming \(F(x)\) to its canonical form by consecutively multiplying the \(i^{th}\) monomial with the product of the first \((i-1)\) monomials requires \(\Theta(d^2)\) multiplications of coefficients.

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 1–2)

I understand that the product of two polynomials each of length \(n\) requires \(n \cdot n = n^2\) multiplications. Each element of the first polynomial must be multiplied by each element of the second polynomial. If both polynomials have \(n\) terms, then their product requires \(n \cdot n = n^2\) multiplications.

Note that a polynomial of the \(d^{th}\) degree has at most \(d+1\) terms.

Choose an integer \(r\) uniformly at random in the range \(\{1, ..., 100d\}\), where by ‘uniformly at random’ we mean that all integers are equally likely to be chosen. Computing the values of \(F(r)\) and \(G(r)\) can be done in \(O(d)\) time, which is faster than computing the canonical form \(F(r)\).

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 1–2)

At this point of the discussion, there is no basis for the value \(100d\). The significance of this value comes at the end of the discussion.

I think what is meant by the final sentence in regards to the time to compute the canonical form \(F(r)\) is that we must first find the canonical form of \(F\), and only then compute \(F(r)\).

Consider the right-wrong scenarios:

  • If \(F(x) \equiv G (x)\), then the randomized algorithm will find the correct answer \(F(r) = G(r)\) for any value \(r\).
  • If \(F(x) \not\equiv G(x)\) and \(F(r) \ne G(r)\) then the randomized algorithm is correct again having found a case where \(F(x)\) and \(G(x)\) disagree.
  • If \(F(x) \not\equiv G(x)\) and \(F(r) = G(r)\), then the randomized algorithm gives the wrong answer.

In the latter scenario, the randomized algorithm finds \(F\) and \(G\) are equivalent because it found one value \(r\) such that \(F(r) = G(r)\).

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 1–2)

If the random algorithm finds a value \(r\) such that \(F(r) = G(r)\), then \(r\) must be a root of equation \(F(x) - G(x)=0\). The degree > of the polynomial \(F(x) - G(x)\) can be no larger than \(d\) and, by the fundamental theorem of algebra, a polynomial of degree \(d\) > > can have no more than \(d\) roots.

Thus, if \(F(x) \not\equiv G(x)\), then there are no more than \(d\) values in the range \(\{1, ..., 100d\}\) for which \(F(r) = G(r)\). Since there are \(100d\) values in the range \(\{1, ..., 100d\}\), the chance that the algorithm chooses such a value and returns a wrong answer is no more than \(1/100\).

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 1–2)

BRILLIANT!!!

1.2 Axioms of Probability

Definition 1.1 (Probability Space) A probability space has three components:

  1. a sample space \(\Omega\), which is the set of all possible OUTCOMES of the random process modeled by the probability space;

  2. a family of sets \(\mathcal{F}\) representing the allowable EVENTS, where each set in \(\mathcal{F}\) is a subset of the sample \(\Omega\); and;

  3. a probability function \(Pr: \mathcal{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) that satisfies Definition 1.2

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 2)

Here, an element of \(\Omega\) is called a SIMPLE or ELEMENTARY event. This is to say that \(\Omega\) comprises a set of outcomes where the only sense of grouping is where each outcome is grouped by itself into its own set, i.e., a simple event. Groups of outcomes constitute an event, where an event denotes a set of outcomes.

In this example, the sample space (the set of possible outcomes) is the set of integers \(\{1, 2, 3, ..., 100d\}\). Any particular choice of an integer \(r\) fro this set is a SIMPLE event.

Definition 1.2 (Probability Function) A probability function is any function \(Pr:\mathcal{F}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}\) that satisfies the following conditions:

  1. for any event \(E\), \(0 \le Pr(E) \le 1\);

  2. \(Pr(\Omega) = 1\);

  3. for any finite or countably infinite sequence of pairwise mutually disjoint events \(E_1, E_2, E_3, ...,\)

\[\begin{equation} Pr \left( \bigcup_{i \ge 1}E_i \right) = \sum_{i \ge 1} Pr(E_i). \end{equation}\]

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 2)

The author notes that they use standard set theory notation when considering events. Namely, they write

\[\begin{equation} E_1 \cap E_2 \end{equation}\]

to denote the occurrence of BOTH events \(E_1\) and \(E_2\) and they write

\[\begin{equation} E_1 \cup E_2 \end{equation}\]

to denote the occurrence of EITHER events \(E_1\) and \(E_2\).

Also, the authors write

\[\begin{equation} E_1 - E_2 \end{equation}\]

to denote the occurrence of an event in \(E_1\) but not in \(E_2\).

And finally, the authors write \(\bar{E}\) as shorthand for

\[\begin{equation} \Omega - E. \end{equation}\]

The notation \(\bar{E}\) denotes the complement of \(E\).

Lemma 1.1 (Union of two events) \[\begin{equation} Pr(E_1 \cup E_2) = Pr(E_1) + Pr(E_2) - Pr(E_1 \cap E_2) \end{equation}\]

(Mitzenmacher and Upfal 2017, 3)

References

  • https://ulyngs.github.io/oxforddown/rmd-basics.html

Mitzenmacher, Michael, and Eli Upfal. 2017. Probability and Computing: Randomization and Probabilistic Techniques in Algorithms and Data Analysis. Kindle. Cambridge, United Kingdom: Cambridge University Press.

## # … with 224 more rows

Showing help on mpg by using ?mpg. Help information prints to the console for R Markdown.

?mpg

Here is my first plot using ggplot. This plot puts displ on the \(x\)-axis, and hwy on the \(y\)-axis, where ‘displ’ denotes engine displacement in liters and ‘hwy’ denotes hwy miles per gallon.

At a minimum, I can see that there is a negative relationship (correlation) between hwy and displ: the greater the displacement, the lower the miles-per-gallon. This makes sense: a gass guzzler (an 8 cylinder car) is going to have bad gas mileage.

plot(cars)

Figure 1: Write your Figure caption here. 

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy))

Figure 2: A plot of MPG with DISPL(y) vs HWY(x)

As an alternative, I may also invoked ggplot using the following syntax:

p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg))
p + geom_point()

The first argument to ggplot() sets the data set to use, e.g., ‘mpg’,

ggplot(data = mpg).

The expression PLUS geom_point() adds a graphic layer to this plot in the form of a scatter plot.

geom_point(mapping = aes(x = displ, y = hwy))

The argument \(x=\) and \(y=\) reference the \(x\)-axis and \(y\)-axis, respectively.

Building up a scatter plot layer by layer.

I begin with the basic data for \(x\)-axis and \(y\)-axis, respectively.

p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg))

Then, I can build the first B&W plot for the data.

p + geom_point()

Next, I can a third variable using color.

p + geom_point(aes(colour = factor(cyl)))

Or, I can that third variable using shape.

p + geom_point(aes(shape = factor(cyl)))

Even still, I can that third variable using size.

p + geom_point(aes(size = factor(qsec)))
## Warning: Using size for a discrete variable is not advised.

Another alternative is to use ALPHA when you have a lot of data

d <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price))
d + geom_point(alpha = 1/10)

d <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price))
d + geom_point(alpha = 1/20)

d <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price))
d + geom_point(alpha = 1/100)

And still another approach is to color line and fill differently

ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +
  geom_point(shape = 21, colour = "black", fill = "white", size = 5, stroke = 5)

References

Wickham, Hadley, and Garrett Grolemund. 2016a. R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data. 1st ed. O’Reilly Media, Inc.

———. 2016b. “R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data.” https://r4ds.had.co.nz/.

item.title: About This Website
item.description:
This website is a running commentary on my study and practice of a new discipline called data science. I call this discipline applied statistics when speaking to my friends and family.

Spring 2021 – Let the games begin! I decided over a year ago to study data science formally through an academic program. To that end, I applied to and was accepted to the Master of Science in Data Science Online at the University of Texas at Austin.

Need for change. For some time, I have been writing software to help kids learn math. After so many years to that end, I decided I needed a venue change: I like software engineering challenges but need a different path. I need new math and computer science challenges, including working with new programming languages, new tools, and new frameworks. For more on why I am affecting a change, see my post on Why I want to be a data scientist.

Getting a degree. While studying data science is not a stretch for me, doing so for a formal degree is: I already have a Ph.D. in Computer Science plus years of experience in software engineering. Learning a new topic is certainly not a surprise choice on my part. I have always been a life-long learner, studying new topics in technology, mathematics, and taxation. I buy used math books through Amazon, subscribe annually to O’Reilly Learning Platform, and most recently signed up for Coursera Plus. Nonetheless, I decided to take the plunge. To learn more, please see my post on Why I chose to pursue a degree in data science.

Attending UT Austin. Many universities offer graduate programs in data science online. So then the question is where should I attend school. I am motivated to attend UT Austin for several reasons, including UT’s commitment to an in-depth mathematical approach to applied statistics, not to mention my hometown attachment to UT Austin. To learn more about my decision, please see my post on Why I decided to attend the University of Texas at Austin.

item.title: Why I decided to attend the University of Texas at Austin for my Master of Science in Data Science
item.description:
Once I decided to study data science through a formal academic program, I only had to determine whose program to attend?

Ultimately, I decided to attend the Master of Science in Data Science (MSDS) Online at the University of Texas at Austin. I gave my decision much consideration. Here are the reasons that motivate my choice.

Every course taught in the MSDS program is a course I want to take. My desired curriculum focuses on using mathematics and statistics, not on using technology. While I value a technical approach to computer science, I don’t believe technology is the starting point for learning data science. As a seasoned computer scientist but a newcomer to data science, I am starting my path with mathematics and applied statistics.

The MSDS curriculum (UTexas 2021), as shown below, illustrates the extent to which UT’s program emphasizes mathematics, statistics, and machine learning. I see only courses that use technology, not lead with technology.

  • Probability and Simulation-Based Inference for Data Science
  • Foundations of Regression and Predictive Modeling
  • Algorithms: Techniques and Theory
  • Advanced Predictive Models for Complex Data
  • Design Principles and Causal Inference for Data-Based Decision Making
  • Data Exploration, Visualization, and Foundations of Unsupervised Learning
  • Principles of Machine Learning
  • Deep Learning
  • Natural Language Processing
  • Optimization

UT created the MSDS program from the ground-up. Clearly, the MSDS program stems directly from data science. Namely, I don’t see any traditional classes in this curriculum from either computer science or applied statistics. That is, the MSDS program is not born of a patchwork of pre-existing courses. Consequently, I anticipate the focus of every discussion to target some aspect of data science. I note that there is no mention of tools, programming languages, or frameworks in this curriculum, which I consider a technical risk but a risk I am willing to take.

The MSDS Program costs a FLAT FEE of $10,000. From my research, no university offers a lower cost Master of Science in Data Science than the University of Texas at Austin, not even Georgia Tech. I consider this pricing disruptive for the industry. While we can all debate the quality of education at one university versus another, we cannot debate the cost. For example, in a recent search, I found the following total costs of a Master of Science in Data Science for eight universities. See Table I below.

Table I. Cost of a Master of Science in Data Science,
assuming six semesters spanning three years.

University Req’d Credits Total Cost
University of California, Berkeley 27 Credits $78,276
University of Southern California 32 Credits $72,644
Syracuse University 36 Credits $64,437
Southern Methodist University 33.5 Credits $60,434
University of Denver 48 Credit $51,456
University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign 32 Credits $21,440
Georgia Institute of Technology 36 Credits $11,706
University of Texas at Austin 33 Credits $10,000

Lower cost means more opportunities. Using my savings, I can travel to Austin for a conference or meet my professors. I can buy more research materials as required. I can attend additional classes in a specialty. Lower cost gives me the flexibility to learn more and take advantage of the opportunities as they arise.

Isn’t the MSDS program too new and untested. Yes, the MSDS program is brand new, starting in Spring 2021, and as such, the program is untested.

So yes, I will be a course guinea pig for probably the entire year, but then after one year, I will be engaged in a program that will be firing on all pistons. For a math-oriented program by a major university that costs dramatically less than its nearest competitor, I am willing to take that risk.

Austin is an exciting place to visit if ever there is such a reason. I have no doubt I will visit Austin soon. I want to meet the professors; I want to see the campus; I want to eat the food; I want to hear the music. Besides, I grew up on the UT Austin campus and therefore always appreciate a return visit to my home state of Texas.

While the global pandemic of 2020 was brutal to every city’s economy, I firmly believe Austin, as a mecca for high tech (Bluestein 2020), will bounce back in stride, if not with a vengeance.

item.title: How to work with BibTeX file in Hugo-Academic
item.description:
The citations feature in Hugo-Academic is based on Pandoc’s Markdown feature for citations, although you do not use Pandoc’s commands directly. When working with citations you must

  1. use a bibliographical file (e.g., .bib),
  2. refer to this bibliographical file in your post’s front-matter, and
  3. include one or more in-text citations,
  4. use the nocite feature without in-text citations.

Bibliographic File(s)

To start, you need a bibliographical file. I am using a BibTeX-formatted file to organize the information for my bibliography.

For the sake of convenience, I am using Mendeley Desktop to manage my bibliographic data, including generating updated versions of my bibtex file, as necessary.

I am keeping my BibTeX (.bib) file in my /static directory under a directory named bib,

$(HOME)/static/bib

Mendeley Desktop

Many of my academic friends swear by Mendeley’s product. So I decided to join them, albeit my only goal here is to manage my bibtex files.

Here are a couple of caveats for handling Bibtex files with Mendeley Desktop (on a Mac).

  1. Under Preferences/BibTeX, turn off "Escape LaTeX special characters (…). By not doing so, I found that Mendeley Desktop left pesky escape strings that improperly mangled my URL strings. I found the fix/recommendation on tex.stackexchange.

item.title: How do I add an image as a figure into a post
item.description:
When adding a figure to a post, my approach depends on the file type I am using. Because I mostly use .Rmd files, I will present my approach for .Rmd tile type here. I describe alternative approaches in another post, Alternatives to how I add an image as a figure into a post.

In my posts, I include an image using the command knitr::include_graphics():

    knitr::include_graphics(<path-to-file>)

For example, I may invoke this command with the following parameters

    {r google-accounts, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Login screen for Google accounts.", out.width=400}
    knitr::include_graphics("images/1-login.png")

where google-accounts is an identifier for my R Chunk, echo=FALSE turns off the input display, fig.cap=“…” is my figure caption, out.width=400 is my desired width (in pixels), and “images/1-login.png” is the relative path to my PNG file.

Several caveats are in order:

  • I am using the R Chunk identifier google-accounts as a means to cite my figure from within my post. I can cite my figure, e.g., Figure 1, using the syntax
    \@ref(fig:google-accounts)

  • The width parameter is dimensionless because HTML’s IMG defaults to pixels for its height and width parameters.

  • My relative path is relative to the page bundle (Hugo 2020) for my post.

   2020-12-24-how-do-i-add-an-image-as-a-figure-into-a-post
   ├── images
   │   └── 1-login.png
   ├── index.en.Rmd
   └── index.en.html

When I use the parameters above with the include_graphic command, I get a final result as shown below in Figure 1.

Figure 1: Login screen for Google accounts.

There are several advantages to using knitr::include_graphics():

  • My invocation required only three lines, including the braces for Chunk R,
  • The value of fig.cap maps to the value for **alt* for the HTML IMG tag,
  • Knitr calculates the running figure # so I do not need to keep track,
  • The named Chunk R is a back reference to the figure, as in Figure 1.
  • Knitr will alter the include_graphic command depending on the output format

Word of caution (frustration) If you want to use include_graphic() to include a file from your /static directory, then you need to turn off errors in knitr. This is quite silly, I think.

See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60292022/knitr-cannot-find-img-files-in-static-folder

I wanted this …

{r utexas-staircase, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Login screen for Google accounts.", out.width=400}
knitr::include_graphics("../../../static/images/staircase.png")

For that matter, I really wanted to use this …

{r utexas-staircase, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Login screen for Google accounts.", out.width=400}
knitr::include_graphics("/images/staircase.png", error=FALSE)

But then I had to use this …

{r utexas-staircase, echo=FALSE, fig.cap="Login screen for Google accounts.", out.width=400}
knitr::include_graphics("../../../images/staircase.png", error=FALSE)

Apparently, include_graphics() uses an uncooked relative path.

Give credit where credit is due. It was only after some time did I trip over the approach described above. To give credit where credit is due, I found Harper (Harper 2018) recommended this approach on StackOverflow. I note that Harper’s source for this information is buried in the documentation for Bookdown (Xie, Dervieux, and Riederer 2021).

References

Harper, Michael. 2018. “Insert picture/table in R Markdown.” https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25166624/insert-picture-table-in-r-markdown.

Hugo. 2020. “Page Bundles.” https://gohugo.io/content-management/page-bundles/.

Xie, Yihui, Christophe Dervieux, and Emily Riederer. 2021. “Figures.” https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/figures.html#figures.

item.title: Why I decided to pursue a degree in data science
item.description:
So you want to be a data scientist? Sounds great! I want to be a data scientist, too. So then the question is, what is the best path to follow.

I decided that working towards a formal degree – an online master’s degree – is the best approach. I do not doubt that everyone learns differently. And I recognize that not only everyone is starting from a different position, but also they are seeking a different end-goal. I should therefore clarify those points first as to the basis of my decision.

Learning is different for everyone. When I learn, I need a well-defined path with both a start and an end. When I read a book, for example, I read every damn page. However, I stop at many points to deep-dive into a question, a challenge, or a background detail. The path keeps me moving forward, while my deep-dive gives me depth and perspective. Yes, I am that person who stops to understand the proofs.

Each of us benefits from different learning styles. At the same time, it is essential to know what particular learning method works best for you. I learn first by reading and then second by doing. Reading allows me the time to absorb the material in-depth and note areas to revisit later. Unfortunately, I cannot rely on listening as my primary means to learn, which is why I require a companion text. Practice problems help, but not as much as a project.

We have different starting points. I already have a Ph.D. in Computer Science, which includes a strong mathematics background (though not a background in applied statistics). Understanding applied statistics, algorithms for machine learning, and data are my challenges, not writing code or learning new technology.

Our end-goals are different. As for my end-goal, I am leaving that choice open for now, albeit my options may range from research to consulting. I know that just as I am learning data science online, I plan to work in data science online.

How I approach learning. Knowing that I plan to listen to content, what I found works best for me is to read and understand the material first and then second use the lecturer’s content to fill in the gap and provide emphasis. My approach implies I need access to written material (e.g., a textbook) for any course I take.

Isn’t academia boring, long, expensive, and out-of-touch? I fully agree that attending a formal program is long, but that’s the only point I agree with here.

A master’s program is time-consuming. But then I plan to hit the ground running from the start when I have useful information to work with for an internship or project. Ken Jee (Jee 2020) calls this having Minimum Viable Knowledge, which is to say, “you should understand just enough of these concepts [in data science] to be able to start exploring your … projects.”

Is a master’s program expensive? Not really. Today’s graduate programs are quite competitive: Georgia Tech is $11,706 out the door, University of Texas at Austin is a flat-fee of $10,000. Remember, too, that this cash outlay spans several years. In the meantime, I plan to capitalize on my investment early.

As for whether an academic program is boring or out-of-touch, I believe that measure depends on me. A master’s program is only as strong as I choose to make it.

So why not just read a bunch of books? I know that I can learn data science through any combination of books. On O’Reilly’s Learning Platform alone, I found nearly 4,000 books with “data science” relevant to their content. Similarly, I found by Google search many a web page that lists today’s must-read books: “50 Must-Read Free Books For Every Data Scientist in 2020” (Verma 2020).

For me, finding a book is not the problem – knowing where to start is my problem. That said, I plan to use my formal study as my primary path and then use supplemental materials along the way.

What about following a self-prescribed curriculum? I agree wholeheartedly. Not only will I develop my own path along the way, but I will also borrow from others’ advice on the same. In particular, I like David Venturi’s (Venturi 2016) planned curriculum. I couldn’t agree more with Venturi’s proposal to study what he wants to learn, when he wants to understand it, and how.

Santiago Víquez Segura [Segura2020] suggests yet another proposal for self-study to include micro-courses by Kaggle. Segura’s suggestions appear attractive and readily achievable, given each micro-course requires less than 4 hours to complete.

I am confident that I will combine my academic work with these self-prescribed curriculums along with curriculum suggestions from others, including Sciforce (Sciforce 2019) and Paruchrui (Paruchuri 2020).

Why not learn through technology by doing, not by studying? I guess so, but I wouldn’t recommend it. I agree that learning through a particular technology grounds you quickly in an application, but doing so also biases you towards one specific train of thought. If all you have is a hammer, then everything looks like a nail. Technologies come and go, if not at least fall into favor or out. Knowing both the why (mathematics, statistics) and the how (technology) is a better, more balanced approach.

Don’t you need a target industry or domain? I do, but for now, I am not targeting a particular industry or field. I am going to see how that plays out as I go along.

Which do you prefer, technology or theory. Ultimately, I decided to start my venture into data science formally. I want to go deep on mathematics and statistics and then learn the appropriate technologies along the way, not vice versa.

References

Jee, Ken. 2020. “How I Would Learn Data Science (If I Had to Start Over).” https://towardsdatascience.com/how-i-would-learn-data-science-if-i-had-to-start-over-f3bf0d27ca87.

Paruchuri, Vik. 2020. “How to Learn Data Science (Step-By-Step) in 2020.” https://www.dataquest.io/blog/learn-data-science/.

Sciforce. 2019. “A Layman’s Guide to Data Science: How to Become a (Good) Data Scientist.” https://medium.com/sciforce/a-laymans-guide-to-data-science-how-to-become-a-good-data-scientist-97927ad51ed8.

Venturi, David. 2016. “My Data Science Master’s: I Dropped Out of School to Create My Own Data Science Master’s– Here’s My Curriculum.” https://davidventuri.medium.com/i-dropped-out-of-school-to-create-my-own-data-science-master-s-here-s-my-curriculum-1b400dcee412.

item.title: Why I want to be a data scientist
item.description:
For some time, I have been writing software to help kids learn math. After so many years to that end, I decided I needed a change of venue: I like software engineering challenges but need a different path.

Specifically, I need to work on more complicated math and computer science; I want to use new programming languages, tools, and frameworks; and I want to work with various domains.

I believe working in data science will give me a new sense of direction. Plus, doing so will satisfy my work requirements more broadly:

  • Work remotely
  • Work in software engineering
  • Work in new areas in computer science
  • Work in a domain with boundless opportunity
  • Work with challenging math

Work remotely. Honestly, I don’t want to move. Of course, I can work locally, but then that would be limiting. Instead, I want to work remotely for whichever company I choose and from wherever I live. Remote work is no longer a limiting choice.

Work in software engineering. I like software engineering, from writing code to designing new architectures. I need more challenging problems, from working with complexity and uncertainty to solving scale and design problems. And I need more math.

I freely admit that writing production code (software engineering) is both demanding and rewarding. However, writing production code is not where I want to focus my energy; instead, I want to work with something new.

Work in new areas in computer science. I am ready to give artificial intelligence a try. I want to solve problems across the board: robotics, vision, natural language processing, planning, machine learning, and deep learning. I can combine my effort in artificial intelligence with my experience in software engineering.

I also want to work with data – lots of data. I am speaking about designing structures, writing algorithms, analyzing complexity, and working with architectures for scale and performance.

Work in a domain with boundless opportunity. When I was a consultant, I always told myself, “there is always room for one in the movie theater.” I don’t need to find the funding for 20 engineers; I only need to find the funding for one (me).

Then again, securing even one seat as a software engineer is hard: you need to write a lot of code. On the other hand, securing a seat as a data scientist could be easy (no production code required): you need a path to a strong recommendation.

Finding the path, not writing the code, is the difference. And, as for finding that path, the sky is the limit.

Work with challenging math. I like the idea of adding complicated math – applied statistics – to my work results. To that end, I am motivated to learn everything I can about applied statistics, machine learning, deep learning and then use today’s technology to build upon that knowledge. I find it interesting that old topics in statistics are now considered fresh and innovative thanks to technological advances.

Separately, I like knowing that the path I want to follow is a data scientist’s path leading to the most desired job. In their article for Harvard Business Review (Davenport and Patil 2012), Davenport and Patil describe the data scientist’s position as just that: “Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century.”

In their article, Davenport and Patil describe a point of innovation at LinkedIn when a scientist – Jonathon Goldman – recognized the implied social connections between LinkedIn’s users. Specifically, Goldman recognized the pattern of “triangle closing”, which is to say that “if you know Larry and Sue, there’s a good chance that Larry and Sue know each other” (Davenport and Patil 2012). And from that discovery, Goldman and his team gave birth to LinkedIn’s feature, “People You May Know,” which launched LinkedIn onto its meteoric path.

Goldman’s discovery stems from the data, not from the code – my point exactly.

References

Davenport, Thomas H., and D. J. Patil. 2012. “Data Scientist: The Sexiest Job of the 21st Century.” https://hbr.org/2012/10/data-scientist-the-sexiest-job-of-the-21st-century.

  • Zoom: Alt + Click

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}

{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes

{{% /speaker_note %}}

  • Press S key to view

  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links

  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}

{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}
